Keywords: Palmitic acid; Nano-TiO2; Thermal analysis; Nano-enhanced organic phase change material; thermal energy storage; thermal conductivity.
Page 1 of 32
Highlights:
 Novel composite of palmitic acid and TiO2 nanoparticles with enhanced
thermal energy storage capabilities.
 The composite is thermally reliable and chemically stable.
 Thermal conductivity of the composite increases significantly with the
loading.
Graphical abstract
Abstract
In the present study, the phase change behavior of prepared novel composites of
palmitic acid and solid nano-particles of titanium dioxide (TiO2) for thermal energy storage have been investigated. The nano-particles are dispersed into the base fluid in various mass fractions (0.5, 1, 3, and 5%) and their effects on the thermo-physical properties have been investigated. Structural analysis has been carried out by using FESEM and crystallography was checked by XRD technique. The chemical/functional groups of the base fluid and composite PCMs have been analyzed by using FT-IR
Page 2 of 32
spectrum. The observations showed that the TiO2 nano-particles do not affect the chemical structure of palmitic acid, however they improve the chemical stability. The phase transition temperature and latent heat of fusion has shown the significant stability with the increase in nano-particle weight fractions. The accelerated thermal cycle test of the composite shows good thermal reliability for 1500 melt/freeze cycles. Thermal conductivity of palmitic acid increased gradually by 12.7, 20.6, 46.6, and 80% for the nano-particle weight fractions of 0.5, 1, 3, and 5% respectively. Based on the results, it can be mentioned that the prepared palmitic acid based nano-enhanced organic phase change composite materials can be very well used as potential solar thermal energy storage materials.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Increasing energy demand and supply gap is forcing researchers to invent new
renewable energy sources or to develop the thermal energy storage devices for efficient energy use. Energy storage systems can facilitate for efficient utilization of renewable energy based technologies to overcome the intermittent nature of energy. At present, the researchers are putting a lot of efforts in developing the different types of solar energy storage systems. Enormous attention has been paid on the latent heat based energy storage systems due to their higher energy density when compared to sensible heat
Page 3 of 32
storage systems and their several applications for solar hot and cold energy storages. The thermal energy storage (TES) using phase change materials (PCMs) offer higherenergy storage density when compared to sensible heat storage. This gives PCMs an advantage of changing the phases at constant temperatures, which enhances the utilization efficiency of the system. Due to a large number of domestic and industrial applications of PCMs for societal needs, they have grabbed the significant attention of researchers in the last few decades.
There are many organic and inorganic PCMs and their eutectics in the different
temperature range which have been investigated in the past years for different applications such as solar heat storage for buildings, drying, water heating, and cold energy storage for peak to off peak demand. Organic phase change materials (O-PCMs), in particular fatty acids, possess high latent heat of fusion, show little/or no supercooling, has congruent melting, and low vapor pressure as well as excellent thermal stability [1]. However, they suffer from low thermal conductivity and this drawback limits their use in many domestic and commercial thermal energy storage applications. Dispersion of solid nano-particles of metal and their oxides in the base OPCM is a proven effective way for enhancing the thermal properties of them [2-5]. Khodadadi and Hosseinizadeh [6], showed in their numerical study that the solidification time of the PCM can be significantly reduced with the increase of nanoparticles dispersion, and the composite of base PCM and nano-particles was named ‘nano-enhanced phase change materials’ (NEPCM) in this study. Since then, NEPCM has attracted significant attention in the research community due to its great potential to store thermal energy.
Page 4 of 32
He et al. [7] prepared the TiO2 based aqueous solution and investigated the
thermal properties of this composite. The results of this study showed that the measured values of thermal conductivity is more than that of what was predicted by HamiltonCrosser numerical model [8]. High conductive metal and/or their oxides are used to enhance the thermo-physical properties of the low thermally conductive organic PCMs, which can later be used in many solar energy storage applications in mini-and-micro scale heat exchangers. In an early work, Bugaje [9] inserted the aluminum metal matrix in the thermal energy storage for thermal conductivity enhancement. The container was filled with paraffin and the author carried out an experimental investigation. The results of this study revealed that the melting time was reduced by a factor of 2.2 and freezing time was reduced by a factor of 4.2. Recently, Alkan et al. [10] prepared the form stable composites of different organic PCMs and supporting materials and found that the supporting materials significantly enhances the thermal conductivity of organic phase change materials. In an another recent study carried out by Lili et al. [11] prepared the form stable phase change material of poly ethylene glycol (PEG) and carbon nanotubes. The results of this study revealed that the melting temperature and enthalpies of composite increase with increasing PEG contents. Similarly, Harish et al. [12] investigated the thermal properties of composite of lauric acid and graphene nanoplates and 230% enhancement in the thermal conductivity was observed by adding only 1% of graphene nanoplate.
Nanofluid which consist of nano-particles or nanotubes of typically 1-100 nm
size, dispersed in the base fluid to overcome the problems associated with poor thermal conductivity of organic PCMs and subcooling. Choi et al. [13] and Jana et al. [14] investigated the effects of Cu nano-particles and carbon nanotubes dispersion (<1%) in
Page 5 of 32
the base PCM and found that the thermal conductivity enhanced by 74% and 150% respectively. Wu et al. [15] studied the effect of Al2O3 nano-particles suspended into water and found that addition of 0.2 wt% Al2O3 nano-particles reduces the solidification time by 20.5%. Altohamy et al. [16] in their recent research further investigated the thermal energy storage behavior of water-Al2O3 nanofluid. A nanofluid of water and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) was prepared by Kumaresan et al. [17] and the effect of MWCNT on the solidification behavior of water based nanofluid was investigated. In this study, the MWCNT was added in the volume fractions of 0.15%, 03%, 0.45%, and 0.6% to deionized water. The results showed that the maximum reduction of 14% and 20.1% in the solidification time were measured for bath temperatures -9 °C and -12 °C respectively.
Harikrishnan et al. [18] investigated the thermal energy storage behavior of
stearic acid-TiO2 composite. The TiO2 nano-particles in the weight fraction of 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.25, and 0.3% were dispersed in the liquid stearic acid using an ultrasonic vibrator. According to these weight fractions of TiO2, 7.03, 12.56, 19.59, 28.64, 35.17, and 43.72% of reduction in the melting time was recorded along with a significant enhancement in the thermal conductivity. A recent study on the thermal energy storage behavior of paraffin/TiO2 composite carried out by Wang et al. [19] reveal that the melting temperature of composite materials reduces when the weight fraction of TiO2 was less than 1%. However, when this fraction is increased beyond 2%, a sharp increase in the phase change temperature and reduction in the latent heat of fusion was observed.
Although, there are many previous studies focusing on the thermal performance
enhancement by dispersing the nano materials and their oxides in various weight factions, but only few of them have considered the titanium dioxide nano-particles for
Page 6 of 32
enhancing the thermal energy storage properties of organic PCMs. The present study aims to accelerate the heat transfer in the O-PCMs by developing a novel nanoenhanced organic phase change materials (NEOPCM) by preparing a composite of palmitic acid and nano TiO2. To the best of our knowledge and from the literature reviewed, it can be mentioned that such composite material has never been prepared before. The TiO2 nano-particles of 21nm average size are dispersed in the liquid palmitic acid in the different wt% (0.5, 1, 3, and 5%) and the thermal energy storage behavior of these composites is investigated. The investigations on their morphology, chemical compatibity, and thermal properties were carried out. The enhancement in the heat transfer rate in PCMs was confirmed by measuring thermal conductivity of composite PCMs. Also, a new correlation to predict the thermal conductivity of NEOPCMs is proposed. The results of the present study reveal that the prepared composites can be effectively used as solar thermal energy storage materials.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text:
Palmitic acid with a melting temperature range of 60-62 °C, molecular weight of
256.43 g/mole, and purity ≥ 98% was purchased from R&M Chemical, UK. Nanoparticles of titanium dioxide (TiO2) anatase form of 21nm, and surfactant Sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate (SDBS) was procured from Sigma–Aldrich, Germany. All the procured chemicals in the experiments were used without any further purification.
2.2 Preparation of composite PCMs
Page 7 of 32
A well-established two-step method as shown in Fig. 1 was adopted for the
preparation of composite PCMs of palmitic acid and different weight fractions of TiO2 nano-particles. Palmitic acid was considered as the base PCM and TiO2 nano-particles in the various fractions 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt% as the supporting materials for thermal conductivity enhancement. The prepared nano-enhanced organic phase change materials (NEOPCMs) were named as NEOPCM1, NEOPCM2, NEOPCM3, and NEOPCM4. While preparing the nanofluid, certain factors were kept in mind, i.e. uniform and stable dispersions, low agglomeration and no chemical reactions between the nano-materials and the base material. SDBS in the ratio 1:1 wt% of TiO2 was used as the capping agent (surfactant) for the uniform dispersions of nano-particles in palmitic acid. Uniform and stable dispersions of nano-particles help in faster melting/freezing rate of PCM due to higher thermal conductivity. In addition, to improve the nano-particle dispersion and minimize the aggregation, the liquid NEOPCMs were subjected to intensive ultrasonication using an ultrasonic vibrator (VCX 500, SONICS made) at a frequency of 40 kHz [20]. Vibrational energy created at this frequency helps to disperse the nanoparticles uniformly into the base liquid PCM. The residing time for 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt% nanofluids were set as 30, 35, 45, 60 minutes respectively. A higher frequency needs lesser residing time and decreases stability in the nanofluid and increases the chances of nanoparticle sedimentation [21, 22]. During the entire sonication process, it was ensured that the temperature of the sonicator remains significantly above the melting temperature of palmitic acid to confirm its liquid state during the process.
2.3 Analysis methods
Page 8 of 32
To ensure the uniform dispersion and to visualize the surface morphology of the
composite PCM, a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM-CARL ZEISS- AURIGA 60) was used. In order to determine the changes in the compositional/functional groups during the cycle test, Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscope (Brand: Bruker, Model: IFS66v/S) has been used between wavenumbers of 400 to 4000 cm -1 with the spectral resolution of 2 cm -1 . Crystalloid phase of NEOPCMs was investigated with an x-ray test conducted by an x-ray diffractometer (XRD: EMPYREAN, PANALYTICAL). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves depicting the thermal stability, and derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) curves depicting the rate of decomposition of composite PCM was obtained by Mettler Toledo TGA/STDA 851-Error ± 5 µg at a heating rate of 10°/min in the temperature range of 50-500 °C.

sections.heading: 2.4 Thermal reliability test
sections.text:
The thermal reliability test of palmitic acid/TiO2 composite NEOPCMs for 1500
thermal cycles was carried out using an accelerated thermal cycle tester. The thermal stability of the NEOPCMs was determined by performing 1500 thermal cycles between
40 and 80 °C. The melting temperature of palmitic acid is nearly 62 C so the
temperature range of 40 to 80 C was chosen in order to ensure that the material gets
melted and solidified completely. The material was heated up to 80 ˚C and then cooled down to 40 ˚C using a fan attached to the machine.
2.5 DSC analysis
Page 9 of 32
The phase change temperature and latent heat of fusion of PA and NEOPCMs
were measured by a differential scanning calorimeter; model METTLER TOLEDO 820C with an error of ± 0.25 °C. All DSC measurements were taken at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min between the temperature 40 and 80 °C. An amount of 6 - 9 mg of PCMs was placed inside a standard 40 µl aluminum pan at room temperature and sealed with a lid to ensure the excellent contact between the sample and the crucible and to avoid leakage when PCM is in liquid state. After this, the sample was carefully placed in the DSC sample tray. The temperature was maintained for 2 min at 40 °C to stabilize the temperature and then heated up to 80 °C. The temperature was again maintained at 80 °C for 2 min to erase the thermal history and then quenched naturally to 40 °C. The DSC measurements were taken before starting the cycling test (0 th cycle) and after the 100 th , 500 th , 1000 th , and 1500 th cycle. Each measurement was taken for at least three times to ensure the repeatability of the results and average of them are presented in this work.

sections.heading: 2.6 Thermal conductivity measurement
sections.text:
The thermal conductivity of the pure PA and NEOPCMs was measured using
the KD-2 pro, which is based on the hot wire technique and a well-established technique for such measurements [20, 23, 24]. All the thermal conductivity measurements were taken when material was in the solid state and at a temperature of 30°C. For this measurement, the pure and composite PCMs were formed into a solid cylindrical form of 5.0 cm length and 2.5 cm diameter using a die and a hydraulic press at a pressure of 1.5 tonnes. Two holes of 1 mm diameter each were drilled on the flat surface of these cylindrical samples. The gap between these holes was kept equal to the distance between the probes of KD-2 pro. The temperature was maintained at a constant of 30 °C
Page 10 of 32
using a water bath. A time gap of 15 min was kept between two subsequent conductivity measurements in order to stabilize the temperature. Three measurements were recorded for each of the composites at this temperature and the average value was considered for reporting.

sections.heading: 3.1 Morphology of palmitic acid and NEOPCM
sections.text:
FESEM images, showing the micro-structural features of nano TiO2 and
NEOPCM4 in the solid state are shown in Fig 2. The spherical shape of the TiO2 nanoparticles can be seen in Fig 2 (a). The FESEM images show the uniform dispersion of TiO2 nano-particles in palmitic acid (see Fig. 2 (b and c)). This is due to the repulsive bond of surfactant. Melting of the NEOPCM around PA lump can be seen at some places due to the electric beam concentration on that particular location of the material, which makes it melt.

sections.heading: 3.2 FT-IR analysis of palmitic acid and NEOPCMs
sections.text:
FT-IR curves of TiO2 nano-particles, PA, and NEOPCM1-4 between wavenumbers of 400 and 4000 cm -1 are shown in Fig. 3. The band at 648 cm -1 corresponds the band stretching vibration of Ti-O. The band between 400 and 800 cm -1 represents the Ti-O vibrations. Two absorption peaks corresponding to 1642 and 3424 cm -1 are characteristic of O-H bending of the hydroxyl group. The peaks at 2918 and 2850 represent the symmetrical stretching vibration of –CH3 and –CH2 group in PA. Nitrile stretch (C=N) appears at around wavenumber 2400 cm -1 . C=O stretching vibration is assigned by a peak seen at 1700 cm -1
. The deformation-vibration of –CH3 and –CH2
Page 11 of 32
group in PA can be recognized at the peak of 1465 cm -1 . The peaks at 1300 cm -1 and 943 cm -1 are corresponding to the in-plane and out-plane bending vibration of the –OH group of PA. The symmetric peaks at 722 and 678 cm -1 corresponds to the swinging vibration of the –OH functional group. FT-IR spectrum of NEPOCM1-4 shows neither any new peaks nor any significant peak shifts in the composite PCMs which signifies that only physical interaction exists between PA, TiO2 and SDBS. These spectra also do not show any chemical rearrangements of the functional group which implies that no chemical reaction takes place between PA and TiO2.

sections.heading: 3.3 XRD analysis of NEOPCMs
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of palmitic acid, TiO2 nano-particles, and NEOPCM2-4. In the XRD pattern on TiO2, the peaks at 25°, 38°, and 48°confirm the anatase form of the nano-particles. In the XRD pattern of pure PA, the peaks at around 2θ = 12°, 20°, 21.5°, 23°, and 30°of are due to the given crystallization. Since NEOPCM1 contains 0.5% TiO2 which is very less to make any significant changes in the physical properties of PA so rest three curves represent the XRD pattern of NEOPCM2-4. It can be found in these curves that peaks at 12°, 21.5°, and 23° are caused by the palmitic acid, and peaks of the TiO2 in the NEOPCM can be seen at 25° and 27.5°. The peak of TiO2 at 25° can be seen in NEOPCM clearly. The intensity of this peak in the NEOPCM is not significant when what % is less than 1%, while it is clearly evident in the NEOPCM 3&4. The results of the XRD patterns indicate that during the preparation of NEOPCMs, the crystal formation of PA did not change and the NEOPCM contains the peaks of both, PA and TiO2.
Page 12 of 32

sections.heading: 3.4 Thermal energy storage properties
sections.text:
Upon increasing the temperature of the PA, the microstructure of the solid PA starts loosening up the compactness which can be inferred as the occurrence of solid-solid phase change. When the temperature is further increased, the molecules of palmitic acid absorb the latent heat and change its phase to liquid, which is the result of the conversion of the absorbed energy into kinetic energy, which overcomes the intermolecular forces. Due to this conversion, the measurements of the latent heat and melting temperature of the material are of paramount importance. DSC analysis has been carried out for measuring the thermal energy storage properties of the pure PA and NEOPCMs of different TiO2 nano-particle weight fractions.
Fig. 5 shows the DSC curves of pure palmitic acid and four prepared NEOPCMs
of 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt% TiO2. The melting point was estimated by the tangent at the point of the highest slope on the face portion of the peak and the latent heat of fusion equal to the area under the curve. It can be clearly seen in the figure that all DSC curves of PA and all NEOPCMs are of similar shape. The measured values of the melting temperature, latent heat of fusion and calculated PCM percentage using Equation 1 are shown in the Table 1.

As can be seen in the figure, the measured latent heat of each composite is smaller
than that of the calculated value and this deviation gets wider with the increase in the wt% of nano-particles. Similar deviations in the measured and calculated values were found in the investigations of Wu et al. [25], Wang et al. [26], and Sari et al. [27]. This deviation ascertains that the equation which is used to calculate the thermal properties of nanofluids cannot be simply used for predicting the thermal properties of solid-liquid PCMs. One of the reasons behind this discrepancy may be surface morphology, structure and dispersion stability of nano-particles in palmitic acid [25]. So, a new model is needed to be developed for solid-liquid PCMs.

sections.heading: 3.5 Thermal stability
sections.text:
Thermal gravimetric analysis was carried out for pure PA and NEOPCM1-
NEOPCM4 to investigate their thermal stability. The high concentration of nanoparticles is likely to sediment and affects the thermal properties maximum, so, it is more interesting to discuss the highest concentration rathe than the lower ones. Therefore, in the present study, the TGA and DTG curves of NEOPCM4 is presented and discussed here. The TGA curve of pure PA and NEOPCM4 is shown in Fig. 7, while Fig. 8 shows the DTG curve of these materials. The weight loss of pure PA occurred between 202 and 282 °C and between 202 and 286 °C for NEOPCM4. Below 200 °C, the weight loss is around 4%, which can be attributed as the removal of absorbed water. The charred residue amount of PA after 500 °C was determined to be less than 0.5% and it remained constant thereafter, so it can be considered that the pure
Page 15 of 32
PA completely degraded at 282 °C, which can be understood as the complete breakage of the polymer chains into monomers. In the case of NEOPCM4, which is the composite PCM of the high nano-particle concentration (5 wt%) in the present study, the charred amount of residue after 500 °C was around 4.5% and this remained constant thereafter. So, the maximum degradation of NEOPCM4 occurred at around 286 °C which is near to that of the pure PCM. This minor delay in the degradation may be due to the fact that the addition of nano-particles in the pure PCM serves as the thermal retardant against the temperature, which results in the delay in the decomposition. So, it can be understood from the TGA and DTG (Fig. 8) curves that the dispersion of nano-particles in the pure PA has improved the stability of this PCM. Since, no decompositions of the material has been noticed until 200 °C, the pure PA and NEOPCMs can be effectively used for cooling/heating applications of building (between 20 and 40 °C) and solar thermal energy storage applications (between 50 and 70 °C).

sections.heading: 3.6 Thermal reliability
sections.text:
An accelerated thermal cycle test was conducted for 1500 melt/freeze cycles and
the melting temperature and the latent heat of fusion were obtained using DSC after 100, 500, 1000, and 1500 cycles. The DSC curves and FT-IR spectrum of pure PA before and after thermal cycle test are shown in Fig 9 (a and b). As can be seen in the Table 1, the maximum jump in the reduction of latent heat of fusion was observed in NEOPCM3, so this composite was selected for thermal reliability test and it was expected that the results of this test can be used for predicting the behavior of other NEOPCMs as well when they undergo an accelerated thermal cycle test. The DSC curves obtained and the thermal properties measured of NEOPCM3 during the cycle test are shown in Fig. 10 and Table 2 respectively. As can be seen in the Fig 9, the latent
Page 16 of 32
heat of fusion of pure PA after 1500 melt/freeze cycles has been degraded by 17.88 %
and melting temperature has been changed by an amount of +1.76 C. This degradation
in the thermal properties is mainly due to two reasons, one is due the impurities present in the material and another is due to the changes in the chemical structure of them. In order to identify the changes in the chemical structure, FT-IR spectrum of PA was taken before and after the thermal cycle test and the curves are presented in Fig. 9 (b). It is clearly visible in the figure that an absorption peak appeared in the pure PA after cycle test at around 3500 cm -1 which is possible due to the impurities present in the material and responsible for degrading the material properties.
Fig. 10 shows the DSC curves and FT-IR spectrums of NEOPCM3 before and
after cycle test. The Table 2 shows that during the thermal cycle test, the melting temperature of NEOPCM3 after 100 th , 500 th , 1000 th , and 1500 th thermal cycles changed by 0.26, -2.05, -1.46, and -0.62 ˚C, respectively. In comparison with the pure PA, a variation of -2.0%, -0.26%, -1.42%, and -2.54% in the latent heat of fusion was observed after 100 th , 500 th , 1000 th , and 1500 th cycles, respectively. It can be understood by looking at the variations in the melting temperatures and latent heat of fusion that the changes are not significant even after a large number of melt/freeze cycles. The depreciation in the latent heat of fusion of NEOPCM3 is within the acceptable level of latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) applications [1]. So, if 300 melt/freeze cycles are considered in a calendar year, these NEOPCMs can be effectively used for a consecutive five years for thermal energy storage in many domestic and industrial applications.
Page 17 of 32
To study the changes in the compositional/functional group of NEOPCMs
during the cycle tests, the FT-IR spectrum of NEOPCM3 before and after the cycle test were obtained and shown in Fig 10 (b). As can be seen in the spectrum, unlike the pure PA, no new peak has appeared after the 1500 melt/freeze cycles and no old peak has disappeared, which signifies that the accelerated thermal cycle test has not affected the chemical structure of the NEOPCM. Accordingly, the PA/TiO2 composite O-PCMs show the stable chemical and thermal properties after such a large number of thermal cycles.
and chemical stability of pure PA significantly. Addition of 3% TiO2 decreases the degradation in the latent heat from 17.88% to 2.4% and melting temperature from 1.76
C to 0.16 C. This enhanced chemical and thermal stability of PA/TiO2 composite
makes them highly suitable for solar thermal energy storage effectively.

sections.heading: 3.7 Thermal conductivity
sections.text:
The energy storage and its discharge rate of the phase change materials is very
much dependent on their thermal conductivity [25]. Higher thermal conductivity increases the heat transfer rate, which in turn increases the melting and solidification process and this leads to lesser solidification/melting time. In the present study, the TiO2 nano-particles of 21nm average size, dispersed in different wt% into the liquid PA and the thermal conductivity of the prepared NEOPCMs was measured in the solid state at a temperature of 30 °C, which is below melting point of pure PA. It is a well-known fact, that if the thermal conductivity is measured at different temperatures, the enhancement in the value of thermal conductivity is not very much significant [28] so, keeping this in
Page 18 of 32
mind, the conductivity has been measured at one particular temperature. The values of measured thermal conductivity against the wt% of nano-particles are presented in Fig. 11(a). As can be seen, the thermal conductivity consistently increases with the increase in the nano-particles weight fraction. The addition of a very small amount of nanoparticles (0.5 weight%, NEOPCM1) increases the thermal conductivity by 12.7%. The enhancement in the thermal conductivity was 20.6%, 46.6%, and 80% in the case of NEOPCM2, NEOPCM3, and NEOPCM4, respectively. This enhancement shows that the thermal conductivity of NEOPCMs is directly proportional to the nano-particle wt%. The nonlinear behavior of the thermal conductivity enhancement is mainly due to the agglomeration caused by a higher percentage of TiO2 nano-particles in the PA [18]. The enhancement of the thermal conductivity also ascertains the lesser melting and solidification time of NEOPCMs compared to pure PA. Supercooling effect in the case of NEOPCMs is also diminished due to the fact that the TiO2 nano-particles dispersed into palmitic acid act as a nucleating agent, which helps in achieving the congruent melting and solidification of NEOPCMs [18]. sections.heading: 3.8 Thermal conductivity analysis in comparison with previous investigations.
sections.text:
Table 3 shows the thermal conductivity and the latent heat of fusion of nano enhanced PCMs prepared in the previous studies based on the nano-particles dispersion of metal oxides such as Al2O3, CuO, SiO2, ZnO, Fe2O3, and TiO2 and the results are compared with the findings of the current study. Wang et al. [19] prepared the nanocomposites of paraffin and nano TiO2 and reported the 13% enhancement in the thermal conductivity with the dispersion of 7% at the cost of 9% reduction in the latent heat. In an another work, Harikrishnan et al. [29] prepared the mixture of stearic acid and lauric, and the nano TiO2 was mixed with them. A dispersion of 1% TiO2 enhanced the thermal conductivity by approximately 42% and a 2% reduction in the latent heat of fusion. In their another work, Harikrishnan et al. [18] prepared a NEPCM of stearic acid and nano TiO2 and they reported that the addition of 0.3% nano TiO2 enhanced the thermal conductivity by approximate 63%. In a recent study, Motahar et al. [30] dispersed the nano TiO2 into organic PCM n-octadecane and found that the dispersion of 5% nanoparticles enhances the thermal conductivity by 26.6%. An addition of 4% Fe2O3, Al2O3, ZnO and SiO2 have also shown the enhanced thermal conductivity of paraffin by 87.5%, 135%, 90%, and 90% respectively [31]. The present study shows an increment of approximately 80% in thermal conductivity when the TiO2 nano-particles dispersion of 5% which can be considered as significant enhancement when compared with the existing NEPCMs. Furthermore, it can be seen in the Table 3 that the latent heat of the pure PA is higher than that of the many PCMs which shows the suitability of this organic candidates in many domestic and commercial energy storage applications. In
Page 20 of 32
addition, the thermal reliability results also ensure the long term use of these NEOPCMs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
This experimental study was conducted on the preparation and characterization
of palmitic acid/TiO2 nano-enhanced organic phase change materials. The TiO2 nanoparticles in 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt% were dispersed into liquid palmitic acid (PA) and the effect of its weight fraction on the thermo-physical properties of NEOPCMs were measured using DSC and thermal conductivity apparatus. The results of this study can be summarized as below:
 The FESEM and XRD images confirmed the uniform dispersion of nano-
particles and FT-IR spectrum showed that the TiO2 nano-particles are in chemical compatibility with PA and the interaction between base OPCM and nano-particles were only physical.
 DSC results of NEOPCMs did not show any significant changes in the
melting temperature, however, a little variation in the latent heat of fusion, confirms its suitability as thermal energy storage materials. The maximum deviation of 3.3% and 15.5% were observed in melting temperature and the latent heat of fusion respectively.
 Accelerated thermal cycle test of NEOPCM showed that the prepared
composite material does not lose its thermal and chemical properties even after a large number of melt/freeze cycles. During the cycle test, the deviation in the melting temperature was found to be in the range of -0.4 to +0.98% and in the latent heat of fusion +0.2 to 2.4%.
Page 21 of 32
 Addition of nanoparticles of TiO2 improves the chemical and thermal
stability of pure PA.
 Thermal conductivity was found to be increasing with the increase of the
loading of nano-particles. An 80% enhancement was seen in the case of NEOPCM4 compared to pure PA. The prepared composites have shown the enhanced thermal properties without significantly affecting the thermal energy storage capacity, so, these NEOPCMs can be used as potential candidates for solar energy storage applications.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, the phase change behavior of prepared novel composites of palmitic acid and solid nano-particles of titanium dioxide (TiO2) for thermal energy storage have been investigated. The nano-particles are dispersed into the base fluid in various mass fractions (0.5, 1, 3, and 5%) and their effects on the thermo-physical properties have been investigated. Structural analysis has been carried out by using FESEM and crystallography was checked by XRD technique. The chemical/functional groups of the base fluid and composite PCMs have been analyzed by using FT-IR
